lead_paragraph: The agreement reached yesterday between Red Cross representatives from North and South Korea on proce dures for a full‐scale conference on divided families followed a near‐breakdown of negotiations last week. That the way is now open for substantive talks covering mail exchanges, mutual visits and possible reunions of families testifies to the new political atmosphere created by the surprise nonaggression agreement concluded last month by the Seoul and Pyongyang Governments. That atmosphere augurs well for success not only on the fam ily problem but on trade and other contacts to normalize relations.

abstract: Despite years of spectacular national economic growth, the political mentality of South Korea's generals remains unchanged. Last weekend's military crackdown showed that power is still wielded by officers trained in the old school of Park Chung Hee. Their political rigidity contrasts with the dynamism that characterizes the rest of Korean society. And their methods have now provoked a formidable challenge in the streets of the provincial capital of Kwangju.

abstract: Donald S Zagoria article on controversy over Pres Carter's plan to gradually withdraw ground troops (M)
snippet: Donald S Zagoria article on controversy over Pres Carter's plan to gradually withdraw ground troops (M)
lead_paragraph: The unconditional withdrawal of the American Second Division from South Korea is ill advised for several reasons. First, it will weaken the deterrent against North Korean aggression. The North Korean border is an hour and a half jeep ride from Seoul; a massed armor attack by the North Koreans at night could have a good chance of reaching Seoul by dawn, even against American air opposition. The North Koreans are now deterred from such a gamble by the automatic involvement of American troops, who must be overcome before they get to Seoul.
headline.main: Korea: To Stay or Not to Stay
headline.print_headline: Korea: To Stay or Not to Stay
byline.original: By Donald S. Zagoria

snippet: Prof Gregory Henderson article on working toward peace in Korea holds US should begin modest trade and cultural contacts with N Korea, make resumed talks between North and South condition of troop withdrawal and restrain undue arms buildups (M)
lead_paragraph: MEDFORD, Mass.—At the base of the whole “Korcagate” stormlet lies poor United States policy on Korea. Had policy been good, not even the manipulatory President Park Chung Hee and his henchmen would have felt called on to bribe Congressmen into supporting it. But policy is bad; and the feckless decision “to withdraw” United States troops from Korea has worsened it.
headline.main: Toward Korean Peace
headline.print_headline: Toward Korean Peace
byline.original: By Gregory Henderson

abstract: Korea emerged as a unified kingdom in 668, but China, claiming a vague sovereignty, did not recognize its independence until late in the 19th century. Following the RussianJapanese war of 1904‐1905, the country became a Japanese protectorate. It was formally annexed by Japan in 1910. After World War II, Soviet and American troops entered Korea, meeting roughly at the 38th parallel, to supervise the Japanese surrender. Efforts to set up a Korean government failed, and the country's division into South and North Korea ensued, with Dr. Syngman Rhee becoming the first President of the newly created Republic of Korea in 1948 when the American military Government ended.
lead_paragraph: Korea emerged as a unified kingdom in 668, but China, claiming a vague sovereignty, did not recognize its independence until late in the 19th century. Following the RussianJapanese war of 1904‐1905, the country became a Japanese protectorate. It was formally annexed by Japan in 1910. After World War II, Soviet and American troops entered Korea, meeting roughly at the 38th parallel, to supervise the Japanese surrender. Efforts to set up a Korean government failed, and the country's division into South and North Korea ensued, with Dr. Syngman Rhee becoming the first President of the newly created Republic of Korea in 1948 when the American military Government ended.

abstract: ed says testimony of former Amb Kim Dong Jo is crucial to investigation, and S Korea's reliance on diplomatic immunity to exempt him from having to testify should be scored (S)
snippet: ed says testimony of former Amb Kim Dong Jo is crucial to investigation, and S Korea's reliance on diplomatic immunity to exempt him from having to testify should be scored (S)
lead_paragraph: Congress can draw only partial satisfaction from the news that South Korea will permit Tongsun Park testify before the House Ethics Committee investigating Korean bribes and favors to members of Congress. It a welcome, if grudging and belated, sign of cooperation from Seoul. But it is not the end of the matter. Mr. Park can advance the committee's inquiry into those lobbying efforts he himself engaged in. But there ample reason to believe that similar efforts were conducted by others, notably Kim Dong Jo, a former Ambassador from Seoul. The committee has insisted that he, too, be made available for questioning, but South Korea continues obdurately to refuse to let him testify.
headline.main: A Stone Unturned on Korea
headline.print_headline: A Stone Unturned on Korea

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 7 (AP) —South Korea's new Government said today that it had authorized four foreign concerns to invest $16 million in three separate projects. One approval was for the Corning International Corporation of the United States to increase its equity investment in the Samsung‐Corning Company. The other approvals called for Lazard Brothers & Company and Barclays Bank International Ltd., both of Britain, to increase their combined capital share in the Korea Merchant Banking Corporation, and for the Lotte Company of Japan to make an additional investment in the Lotte Livestock Company.

snippet: editorial holds that US officials should urge South Korean Government and its military junta now in control to lay foundations for durable, essentially democratic state
lead_paragraph: For the third time since 1948, South Koreans have the chance to lay the foundations of a durable, essentially democratic state. This time, with luck and the right kind of American encouragement, the cement may set. Even before the murder of President Park Chum Hee. it was apparent that his one‐man rule was obsolete in a nation that his economic policies had transformed. While economic power was diffused, political power was not. The system he created courted the violent end that not even his ring of bodyguards could prevent.

abstract: Civiletti biog; his por
snippet: Civiletti biog; his por
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16—Last February, shortly after Benjamin R. Civiletti took office as head of the Justice Department's criminal division, Attorney General Griffin B. Bell asked the outgoing head of the division, Richard L. Thornburgh, if he was in terested in staying on as a special prosecutor in the case of alleged Korean influence‐buying in Washington. Mr. Thornburgh declined, and then told Mr. Bell with a smile that he thought it only fair that Mr. Civiletti himself should assume “the problems as well as the pleasures” of the job.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)—The International Monetary Fund said today a drawing of up to $20‐million Special Drawing Rights had been approved for South Korea through this year. The drawing authority is $10‐million special drawing rights below an earlier arrangement which the Koreans never had to use. The fund said “in August, 1972, Korea took strong policy measures to stabilize the price level, after an accelerated increase in the first seven months of the year. Significant gains were made in 1972 in improving the balance of payments position, including roughly halving the trade deficit.”

lead_paragraph: Once again, the United States finds itself in the role of the pitiful, helpless giant, the unhappy hostage of a small foreign land. Once again, the country is trapped by its own antiquated policy. Here it is carrying on a vast program of military aid—including the current commitment of 38,000 American troops—to provide an ally with protection from the spread of Communist totalitarianism when the ally itself has turned into a distasteful police state. Is it not time, then, to rethink the policy that led us to this circumstance? Or, are there still, in spite of everything, compelling reasons,

abstract: rev of scandal, and factors which have impeded investigation of matter; '74 incident in which S Korean security chief Park Chung Kyu tried to give money to White House aide John Nidecker recalled; cartoon strip illustrating incident (M)
snippet: rev of scandal, and factors which have impeded investigation of matter; '74 incident in which S Korean security chief Park Chung Kyu tried to give money to White House aide John Nidecker recalled; cartoon strip illustrating incident (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—On a Sunday afternoon in May, 1974, a White House official named John Nidecker was preparing to leave Seoul when the powerful chief of the Presidential security service; Park Chong Kyu, pressed into his hand at a golf club an envelope —a parting gift—and wished him a good trip home. On the way to the airport, Mr. Nidecker tore off corner of the envelope. it was full of American money. He quickly handed it to an embassy officer, who explained to Ambassador Philip Habib the next morning what had happened and handed the envelope on to him. Mr. Habib ripped it open and counted out onto his desk 510,000 in $100 bills. He summoned the station chief of the Central Intelligency Agency, Donald Gregg, and instructed him to get the money back to Mr. Park. Mr. Gregg promptly did so.
headline.main: Korean Probe and Why it Dragged On
headline.print_headline: Korean Probe and Why it Dragged On
byline.original: By Richard Halloran

lead_paragraph: Under the auspices of three Korean‐American cul tural organizations, Young W. Hong made her New York debut Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. No biographical information was circulated about the Korean soprano, but Miss Hong's confident stage manner sug gested that she is no stranger to concert audiences. Her substantial voice has a pleas ing timbre, sweet in the low and mid‐ranges, and her sing ing has considerable musical ity, too.

lead_paragraph: Has the chill of repression already snuffed out this autumn's “Seoul spring”? The authoritarian spirit the slain Park Chung Hee seems to carry on in the recent actions of some of his heirs. Their behavior adds weight to the case for urgent constitutional reform and early elections. What chance remains for a more open political system depends on whether the newly chosen President, Choi Kyu Hah, can regain the momentum of a once‐promising transition process.
headline.main: President Choi's Chance in Korea

abstract: SEOUL, March 5 (Reuters)—Fourteen people were killed today when a fire swept through a four‐story building in the center of the city. Authorities said the fire raged through the building's two upper floors while dozens of fire engines stood useless outside because hydrants had frozen in the 5‐degree weather.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, March 5 (Reuters)—Fourteen people were killed today when a fire swept through a four‐story building in the center of the city. Authorities said the fire raged through the building's two upper floors while dozens of fire engines stood useless outside because hydrants had frozen in the 5‐degree weather.

lead_paragraph: Images of a word: For a generation, “Korea” to Americans connoted a feisty Harry Truman and a bold, costly defense of American vital interests. Today, it connotes a malodorous scandal involving payments to Congressmen to favor South Korean interests. South Korea refuses to cooperate with American investigations this “Operation White Snow.” By now, the Seoul Government must be starting to weigh the price of its obduracy.
headline.main: White Snow, Clean Hands and Korea
headline.print_headline: White Snow, Clean Hands and Korea

lead_paragraph: The news from South Korea is dismal and ??miliar President Park is cracking down on political opponents again; midnight raids, arrests, surveillance, break‐ins. More than 30,000 Americans died in South Korea's defense, and billions of dollars have been spent over a generation to protect it against aggression by Communist North Korea, a police state. But the South remains a police state, too. Must our sense of strategic obligation render us helpless against the most brazen violations of human rights?
headline.main: South Korea: Our Indecent Ally

abstract: Prof Donald S Zagoria article holds that Pres Carter's planned troop withdrawal would intensify rather than diminish risk of becoming involved in another Asian land war; illus (L)
snippet: Prof Donald S Zagoria article holds that Pres Carter's planned troop withdrawal would intensify rather than diminish risk of becoming involved in another Asian land war; illus (L)
lead_paragraph: Albert Wohlstetter once remarked that not the least of the tragedies of Vietnam would be the “lessons” we learned from it. More dryly, historian James C. Thomson made the same point. The only, lesson we should learn from Vietnam, he said, is never again to fight a nationalist movement dominated by Communists in a former French colony. Unfortunately, all the indications are that President Carter's sudden and fateful decision to withdraw the United States Second Infantry Division from South Korea stems from a Vietnam trauma that still has the President and many of his younger aides in its grip.
headline.main: WHY WE CAN'T LEAVE KOREA

lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Sept. 4 (AP) After a threeyear depression that hit bottom in 1977, North Korea's economy is showing some improvement. abstract: Fed grand jury in Washington, DC, indicts Hancho C Kim for allegedly lying to grand jury and conspiring to defraud US; charges stem from probe of alleged S Korean influence-buying in Cong; indictment reveals that alleged effort had code name Operation White Snow, and that Kim used rented telecommunications equipment to send messages directly from his Md home to Korean CIA hq in Seoul; charges that Kim received at least $600,000 in US currency to support operation, but does not describe how money was spent or name Cong recipients, if any; indictment appears to rely heavily on testimony of Kim Sang Keun, former Korean intelligence officer who defected and who is named an unindicted co-conspirator, as is Gen Yang Doo Wan, former KCIA station chief in US; indictment notes that Hancho Kim caused 2 articles favorable to Korean Govt to be inserted in Cong Record by Repr Tennyson Guyer and former Repr Vernon W Thomson; Hancho Kim, who is naturalized Amer citizen, protests his innocence; he and wife, Soon Duk Sim, are also under indictment for income tax evasion in 74 and '75 (M)

abstract: in apparent attempt to speed present series of pol trials in Seoul, S Korea, 26 more persons are convicted of subversion on Aug 8 and 19 others are placed on trial; spokesman for Ministry of Natl Defense says that 26 defendants, ranging in age from 18 to 48, received prison terms of 3 to 15 yrs; sources believe that majority of defendants are students; all 45 are charged with involvement in alleged Communist plot to overthrow Govt of Pres Park Chung Hee last Apr; plot is said to have been led by Natl Democratic Youth Student League; 19 defendants taken before mil tribunal brings to 79 number of new cases acknowledged by Govt in last 2 days; 91 persons were convicted in earlier courts martial under sweeping emergency decrees proclaimed this yr by Park and 5 more prominent Koreans are before other mil cts; Park is reptdly making all decisions on who will be tried and when; Park is said to be determined to complete all trials as rapidly as possible despite widespread internatl criticism and mounting concern among Korean officials; at same time, there is growing speculation that after sentences are all handed out, Park will move to reduce them drastically and possibly change some of his emergency decrees; Premier Kim Jong Pil has said that 1st phase of emergency measures will be completed in not so remote future (M)

abstract: US and S Korea fail to reach new textiles agreement and further round of negotiations is expected (S)
snippet: US and S Korea fail to reach new textiles agreement and further round of negotiations is expected (S)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (Reuters)—The United StateS and South Korea have so far failed to reach a new textiles agreement and a further round of negotiations is expected in Washington or Seoul at the end of this month, United States Administration sources said today. The two sides end a current round of discussions here tomorrow. The sources described the sessions as very friendly and stressed that both sides want a new agreement to replace the current threeyear accord, which expires on Sept. 30.

abstract: 76-ton ferry boat carrying over 100 passengers runs aground in dense fog on Jan 25 and sinks off Seoul, S Korea; rescue efforts are suspended at nightfall, following recovery of 13 bodies; sources speculate final death toll will be much greater
snippet: 76-ton ferry boat carrying over 100 passengers runs aground in dense fog on Jan 25 and sinks off Seoul, S Korea; rescue efforts are suspended at nightfall, following recovery of 13 bodies; sources speculate final death toll will be much greater
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 25 (UPI)—A 76‐ton ferry boat with more than 100 passengers aboard ran aground and sank in dense fog off the southwestern tip of Korea today. Rescue efforts suspended at nightfall after policemen had recovered 13 bodies. Unofficial sources said the death toll could be much higher.

abstract: 7 persons killed and 59 injured as bus plunges into valley near Seoul; 4 persons killed and 16 injured when bus careens off rd near Taegu; both accidents occur on Feb 6
snippet: 7 persons killed and 59 injured as bus plunges into valley near Seoul; 4 persons killed and 16 injured when bus careens off rd near Taegu; both accidents occur on Feb 6
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 6 (UPI) —At least 11 persons were killed in two separate bus accidents today. A bus with about 80 persons aboard plunged into a valley from a narrow countryside road about 65 miles south of Seoul, The police reported that seven persons were confirmed killed and 59 injured, many seriously. In the other accident, four persons were killed and 16 injured when a bus careened off the road near Taegu, about 150 mile southeast of Seoul.
headline.main: Korea Bus Accidents Kill 11

abstract: Article on Korea's revolutionary poet Kim Chi Ha, progenitor of epic satire Five Bandits whose publication in 70 resulted in his trial and arrest; petition for his release included signatures of N Chomsky, J-P Sartre and H Marcuse; Kim regards self as patriotic figure rather than radical activist and seeks opportunity to write freely; Kim por; excerpts from Five Bandits
snippet: Article on Korea's revolutionary poet Kim Chi Ha, progenitor of epic satire Five Bandits whose publication in 70 resulted in his trial and arrest; petition for his release included signatures of N Chomsky, J-P Sartre and H Marcuse; Kim regards sel...
lead_paragraph: SEOUL. He writes with a toughness that has enraged the leaders of his country and resulted in mass arrests and trials. He pierces the walls of hypocrisy and corruption around him with the force of a meat ax—or the subtlety of a needle. He evokes the national tragedy of his people but does it so cleverly that his readers often laugh instead of weep. He has been arrested and tried, held without trial, committed to a tuberculosis sanitarium, hunted and followed ever since a small magazine published his epic satire, “Five Bandits,” nearly three years ago. After the publication of another poem, “Groundless Rumors,” he went into hiding in an obscure hotel room while more than 150 of his friends were seized and questioned about his whereabouts.
headline.main: In Korea, officials curse, intellectuals cheer
headline.print_headline: In Korea, officials curse, intellectuals cheer

snippet: Concert by pianist Soomi Lee and violinist Young Sun Choi, sponsored by Korean Community Activity Center, revd by J Rockwell
lead_paragraph: The joint recital offered Friday evening by the Korean Community Activity Center at Carnegie Recital Hall turned out to be something of a mismatch. Soomi Lee, a 16‐year‐old native of Seoul who is in the pre‐college division of the Juilliard School, is no doubt a promising pianist. But at this stage of her career she plays most of the notes without investing them with much personality, and major midtown exposure like this seemed premature.

abstract: impact of oil shortage on country discussed (L)
snippet: impact of oil shortage on country discussed (L)
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 8 —The first thing that strikes the visitor after several months' absence from Korea is the leap in prices. The taxicab from the airport to the hotel that once cost $2.50 has become $3.25. A meal that was $1.75 is now $2.28. A gallon of gasoline, formerly 60 cents, is now $1.80. A newspaper headline reports price increases on industrial products ranging from 7 to 57 per cent.

snippet: H B Rogers Jr article describes visit to Cheju City, S Korea, and its environs including famed Chonjeyon Waterfall and Cheju‐do, island known for its women divers; illus
lead_paragraph: T'HE plane from Seoul, South Korea's capital, dipped through the clouds to reveal a bright yellow and green checkerboard, just above the sea, from which a few whimsical barren hills abruptly jumped. The green was intense. and flourishing, but the yellow was amazing. Safflower was in full bloom. The fields were neatly separated by dark lava‐rock walls, which also surrounded low burial mounds. Far off a slope began; beyond was the volcano Halla‐san (Mt. Halla).

abstract: Biog sketch (M)
snippet: Biog sketch (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 22—For several days Kim Hyung Wook said he had been getting ominous telephone calls from unknown Koreans warning him not to testify before a House subcommittee today. But the former director of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency, no stranger to violence or threats of violence, said his piece anyway. A chunky, powerful man who looks a decade younger than his 52 years, Mr. Kim has been soldier, revolutionary, intelligence officer, politician and exile. He fought as an infantry troop commander in the Korean War, was among the young colonels who led a coup d'état to take power in 1961 and was a member of the ruling junta for two years

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 7—Imprisoned political dissidents, some of whom began jail life last spring with 10 days of nonstop interrogation, are being subjected to a spartan life of solitary confinement in small cells with meager, monotonous meals and no furniture. lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—In August 1973, Korean Central Intelligence agents in Tokyo, under personal orders from President Park Chung Hee, kidnapped a Korean opposition leader called Kim Dae Jung and took him back home. The Japanese were furious. Contending that their national sovereignty had been violated, they demanded that Mr. Kim be returned. President Park's Government, correctly sensing that the Japanese Government would feel there was nothing they could do about it, stood fast, and eventually mumbled an apology about overzealous agents. Mr. Kim Is in prison in Seoul today.

abstract: Performance of Korean court music and dance will be performed at Carnegie Hall on December 7; to be sponsored by Asia Society (M)

lead_paragraph: The opening number in a program of Korean court music and dance that will be given one time only at Carnegie Hall this evening is a fanfare of traditional military music. It is the music that once charted the progress through their realm of Korean kings — among them. royalty of the Yi dynasty,which lasted 500 years and began exactly a century before the discovery of America. The music will be played on instruments equally ancient in origin: onetone trumpets, oboes, conch shells, drums, gongs and cymbals.
headline.main: Courtly Arts From Korea At Carnegie Hall Tonight
headline.print_headline: Courtly Arts From Korea At Carnegie Hall Tonight

abstract: Article on planning by US Armed forces to meet global military contingencies; illus (M)

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As soon as they heard that Iranian militants had captured the United States embassy in Teheran, planning officers in the Pentagon began pulling books crammed with information on Iranian airfields, ports, transport, terrain, locations, water supplies and a myriad of other details out of thick steel files. No one had to tell them to do that because their assignment, once such an emergency flares, is to draw up a range of contingency plans for the deployment of American military forces.

abstract: Donald W Shriver Jr (Union Theological Seminary) article on oppression practiced by current Amer‐backed S Korean regime
snippet: Donald W Shriver Jr (Union Theological Seminary) article on oppression practiced by current Amer‐backed S Korean regime
lead_paragraph: As we sat, in South Korea, in the building overlooking “Freedom Bridge” on the river Imjin, he said: “Sometimes, when I come up here to the DMZ, I get literally sick. That's my birthplace up there. My father was a Presbyterian minister. In 1950 the Communist troops came through our town, dragged him out of the house, and shot him dead. We found his body in the river, roped to four others. Now here I am, a college professor well known among Government people as a critic of this regime. Some of them know my experience in the war. They know I have little reason to love the North Korean style of government. They are puzzled that I don't join them in their wild zeal for ‘national security.’ When will they understand that security, by itself, is meaningless? What good is security if its price is the loss of our liberty? Right here the Govern ment has built a marble monument to ‘Americans who fought for our liberty.’ Where is the liberty you fought for?”
headline.main: ‘Security First, Democracy Second’ Is Wrong, the South Korean Said
headline.print_headline: ‘Security First, Democracy Second’ Is Wrong, the South Korean Said
byline.original: By Donald W. Shriver Jr

abstract: Newly declassified documents obtained by NY Times show that US gave high-level consideration during Korean War to stage coup against S Korean Pres Syngman Rhee; plan, which called for Rhee's arrest, was known as Operation Everready and was never put into effect on 2 occasions it was under active study; Rhee made concessions that, in view of Amers involved, made his overthrow unnecessary and undesirable; Amer mil officers and diplomats who conceived operation said before and after that they had high regards for Rhee's leadership and respected his deep anti-Communist convictions, even though they often sharply disagreed with his repressive pol policies; documents were declassifed by Defense and State Depts at Kotch's request under Freedon of Information Act; some documents were obtained independently by NY Times; contents of documents noted; illus (L)

abstract: Prince Sihanouk says, July 13, Peking, he will leave next wk for a 3‐wk visit to N Korea and will not meet H A Kissinger, Nixon's natl security adviser, when he comes to Peking; says even if he is in Peking when Kissinger arrives, he will refuse to meet him or allow any member of his exiled govt to do so; expresses pessimism over chances of a settlement in Cambodia; says he has no confidence that US bombing will end on Aug 15; says any meeting with Kissinger will give Nixon excuse to tell US Cong and Amer people that negotiations are going on; says this will give him leverage with Cong to continue bombing after Aug 15 deadline in hope that attacks will force Sihanouk supporters to the conf table to negotiate a cease‐fire; says his forces will continue to fight until final victory, even if it take 10 yrs or more; says settlement could come about only through a complete halt in US air attacks and elimination of ‘traitorous’ Lon Nol Govt; says he has no information about reptd return to Peking, to rept on Cambodia, of Chinese repr to US, Amb Huang Chen, after meeting last wk with Nixon; says Chinese Premier Chou En‐lai will never interfere in the affairs of his exiled Cambodian Govt or give any hope to the Amers as far as a Cambodian settlement was concerned; renews appeal to China and Vietnam for arms and ammunition for his forces; latter stopped supplying arms after signing of Vietnam truce; Sihanouk says N Korean Premier Kim Il Sung offered him arms aid
snippet: Prince Sihanouk says, July 13, Peking, he will leave next wk for a 3‐wk visit to N Korea and will not meet H A Kissinger, Nixon's natl security adviser, when he comes to Peking; says even if he is in Peking when Kissinger arrives, he will refuse t...
lead_paragraph: PEKING, July 13 (Reuters)—Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed Cambodian head of state, said today that he would leave next week for a threeweek visit to North Korea, and would not meet Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, when he comes to Peking.
headline.main: Sihanouk to Visit North Korea During Kissinger's China Stay
headline.print_headline: Sihanouk to Visit North Korea During Kissinger's China Stay

abstract: WASHINGTON, July 25—Kim Han Cho, a relatively unknown South Korean who is alleged to have been an agent of his country's Central Intelligence Agency, distributed $200,000 in cash gifts and favors to American officials and members of Congress up until a year ago, according to a former director of the agency. Kim Hyung Wook, the former intelligence head, said in an interview that the money was spent from mid‐1975 to mid1976. In previous testimony before House subcommittee he identified Kim Han Cho as the source of some Korean largesse.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 25—Kim Han Cho, a relatively unknown South Korean who is alleged to have been an agent of his country's Central Intelligence Agency, distributed $200,000 in cash gifts and favors to American officials and members of Congress up until a year ago, according to a former director of the agency. Kim Hyung Wook, the former intelligence head, said in an interview that the money was spent from mid‐1975 to mid1976. In previous testimony before House subcommittee he identified Kim Han Cho as the source of some Korean largesse.
headline.main: Korean Businessman Linked to $200,000 in Gifts to U.S. Officials in 75‐76
headline.print_headline: Korean Businessman Linked to $200,000 in Gifts to U.S. Officials in 75‐76

lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 26 —Harry S. Truman, the 33d President of the United States, died this morning. He was 88 years old.

abstract: Park shot to death during reported dispute between Korean CIA Dir Kim Jae Kyu and chief bodyguard; illus (M)
snippet: Park shot to death during reported dispute between Korean CIA Dir Kim Jae Kyu and chief bodyguard; illus (M)
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Oct. 27 — President Park Chung Hee, South Korea's ruler for more than 18 years, was fatally shot last night by the chief of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency at a restaurant near the presidential resi- dence, the Government announced early today. It said the death of the President was “the result of an accidental argument” between the agency chief and the Mr. Park's chief bodyguard.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4—Officials of thy Carter Administration and the Defense Department are proposing the relocation of. 14,000 troops from South Korea to three bases in the Northeast. They are Fort Drum, N.Y.; Fort Dix, N.J., and Fort Devens. Mass.

abstract: KWANGJU, South Korea, May 31-- Shortly before dawn today the heavy tanks that had occupied the center of this provincial capital since Tuesday cranked up their engines and rumbled off to the suburbs. A couple of hours later the big fountain in the main square came back to life, spraying water into the air.
headline.main: As Tanks Rumble Off, a Korean City Springs Back to Life; Woman Scuffling Along the Road Emotional Scars Remain Obscured
headline.print_headline: As Tanks Rumble Off, a Korean City Springs Back to Life; Woman Scuffling Along the Road Emotional Scars Remain Obscured
byline.original: By Henry Scott Stokes Special To the New York Times

abstract: It begins as if it were going to be a solemn documentary about the horrors of capital punishment. We see the prison buildings in a long shot from the air. The narrator describes the death house as looking like any other ordinary house, situated on a small hill, and we cut to the interior of the execution building.The narrator tells us that the walls are salmon pink (the film is in black and white) and notes that it has toilet facilities only for men. He invites us to watch a typical execution, which is when things go awry. Quite wildly. The heart of the victim, a young Korean convicted of two rape-murders, refuses to stop beating after the hanging. The execution team panics.The prosecutor says that the man cannot be re-executed until he is restored to consciousness, but the doctor, who had intended only to verify death, is without his medical bag.The Roman Catholic chaplain says it would be murder to hang the man again since the man's soul, which is responsible for the crimes, has left the body. Meanwhile the victim comes to and wonders where he is. The doctor is dumbfounded: He's never before heard of amnesia after an execution.For about one-third of its running time Nagisa Oshima's Japanese film "Death by Hanging" is a surprisingly uproarious contemplation of the moral issues involved in capital punishment. The prison officials, prosecutors, chaplain and witnesses argue back and forth and pick at each other with a Lewis Carroll sort of purposeful, cross illogic. Everybody becomes nettled. Someone suggests that they call it a day. "This kind of work has its failures too," he says, but they all stay on to straighten things out, sort of."Death by Hanging," which was made by Mr. Oshima in 1968, was shown at the First Avenue Screening Room last Sunday, and will be repeated there again today and tomorrow at noon and midnight.It is the second Oshima film to open in New York in a week, and though it is less complex than "The Ceremony," which was made in 1972, it is no less schematic. It's the kind of didactic work that only Jean-Luc Godard has ever successfully transformed into film, not because Mr. Godard is such a brilliant political philosopher, which he isn't, but because his brilliance as a film maker is irrepressible.On the basis of these two films, Mr. Oshima is certainly talented as well as hugely concerned and committed to the sort of cinema that plays an active role in its society. As long as "Death by Hanging" sticks to capital punishment, it is, in its absurd way, provocative and entertaining. But the film's interests keep widening, its methods become increasingly, arbitrarily Godardian (read Brechtian), until it reaches a point of total confusion.In order to be able to execute the murderer again, the prison team decides it must convince the man who he is (his name is simply R). They act out charades designed to make R remember. Involved are his identity as a murderer, as well as his identity as a Korean, a people long oppressed by the Japanese. Kafka, Freud and some other weighty presences are evoked by Mr. Oshima as straight editorializing, through Godardian monologues. One of R's problems is that he loved his sister, which doesn't seem to have a great deal to do with legalized murder and capital punishment.Some of it is funny. More of it is tedious, and a lot of it curiously old-fashioned, even though it reminds us of the great Godard films of the mid-nineteen-sixties. Extreme movie styles date more quickly than hemlines.

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 1 — Senior army generals meeting in secret here this week have informally decided to scrap the Constitution that was the legal foundation of President Park Chung Hee's power, according to sources close to the military today.

abstract: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 11-- American officials have appealed to the military junta to spare the life of Kim Dae Jung, the opposition leader whose trial on charges of sedition is due to start this week. abstract: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--Political instability in South Korea that may tempt North Korea into adventurism will be the primary issue in Asia to confront the Reagan administration in January, according to the President-elect's State Department transition team.

byline.original: By Richard Halloran Special To the New York Times

abstract: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 13--Kim Dae Jung, in a final appeal before a court-martial trying him for treason, denied today that he ever plotted to overthrow the Government and appealed for a speedy return to democracy in South Korea.
headline.main: DISSIDENT IN SEOUL MAKES A FINAL PLEA; At End of Trial, Kim Dae Jung Says He Did Not Seek to Overthrow South Korea Government Demonstration Held by Relatives 'Moral Responsibility' Accepted Details of Interrogation Given

byline.original: By Henry Scott Stokes Special To the New York Times

abstract: A few years ago, the executive corps of J. Manheimer Inc., a $20-milliona-year producer of flavoring ingredients in Queens, decided it was time for a foreign adventure. "We didn't really go after foreign sales until then," said Arnold L. Manheimer, vice president and treasurer of the family concern.

abstract: SEOUL, South Korea, May 22 The South Korean military authorities took the first steps today toward trying the opposition leader Kim Dae Jung on sedition charges by issuing a 14-page preliminary report saying they have evidence that he planned to overthrow the Government.

abstract: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 8--Gen. Chon Too Hwan, the South Korean strongman, said in an interview today that South Koreans "need a new generation of leaders" and he implied that he was willing to serve as head of state in succession to the civilian President, Choi Kyu Hah.

abstract: SEOUL, May 20--The South Korean Cabinet of Prime Minister Shin Hyon Hwack resigned today "to take responsibility for failure to maintain domestic calm" as riots continued in the provincial city of Kwangju.

abstract: SEOUL, South Korea, Sunday, May 18 -- Faced with the most serious student political unrest in 20 years, the South Korear Government announced this morning that it was closing the universities, prohibiting political gatherings and labor strikes, imposing rigorous press censorship and extending martial law to the entire country.
headline.main: TOUGH STEPS TAKEN BY SEOUL TO QUELL STUDENTS' PROTESTS; MARTIAL LAW POWER WIDENED Campuses Are Closed, Censorship Set and Gatherings Curbed -- Critics of Regime Seized Meeting Stormed by Riot Police South Korea Acts to Curb Protests

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Nov. 3 — Kim Dae Jung, who spent years in prison for his opposition to the late President Park Chung Hee, broke an unofficial moratorium on political activity yesterday by calling for the direct election of a new President and pointedly urged the United States to keep the South Korean military out of the succession process.

abstract: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25—Suzy Park Thomson, who was threatened yesterday with a contempt of Congress citation for refusing to testify in the investigation of Korean influence buying, was questioned at a five‐hour closed session today by members of the House ethics committee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25—Suzy Park Thomson, who was threatened yesterday with a contempt of Congress citation for refusing to testify in the investigation of Korean influence buying, was questioned at a five‐hour closed session today by members of the House ethics committee.
headline.main: The New York Times/Teresa Zabela TISCTIFIES IN KOREAN‐INFLUENCE CASE: Suzi Park Thomson, accom­panied by her niece, Carol Huh, arriving for five hours of questioning behind closed doors before House ethics committee in Washington. Page A9.

abstract: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)--Lee Hahn-Been, South Korea's Deputy Prime Minister, signed an agreement today for $1.1 billion in reduced-interest loans from the United States Export-Import Bank to build two 997megawatt nuclear plants. The plants will be built in Gyaema, South Korea, for the Korea Electric Company and should be completed in 1986 and 1987. The nuclear reactors will be supplied by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

abstract: Officials concerned over Pres Carter's decision to lift travel curbs on foreigners living permanently in US; are worried it will allow S Korean residents in US to travel freely to N Korea, prohibited to all S Korean residents (S)
snippet: Officials concerned over Pres Carter's decision to lift travel curbs on foreigners living permanently in US; are worried it will allow S Korean residents in US to travel freely to N Korea, prohibited to all S Korean residents (S)
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, April 16—South Korean officials expressed concern today over President Carter's decision to lift travel restrictions on foreigners living permanently in the United States. They are worried that this will allow South Korean residents of the United States to travel freely to North Korea, something that is prohibited for all citizens of South Korea.
headline.main: Seoul Nervous Over Carter Move To End Travel Curb for Aliens
headline.print_headline: Seoul Nervous Over Carter Move To End Travel Curb for Aliens

abstract: SEOUL, South Korea, July 4—South Korea asked North Korea today to resume political negotiations broken off by the North four years ago. A statement by the South Korean delegation to the suspended talks said that resumption of contacts was essential The statement commemorated the fifth anniversary of the signing of a communiqué that promised that the two Koreas would work for peaceful settlement of differences, and renewed a demand that a treaty of noninterference and nonaggression be signed.

abstract: Divided Korea is an unfortunate and unintended legacy of the Second World War and subsequent developments in the Cold War. The initial division was externally imposed, against the wishes of the Korean people. According to a pre‐arranged agreement, the country which had been under Japanese colonial rule for thirty‐five years, was divided along the 38th parallel, with the Soviet Union taking military control in the north and the United States in the south.

lead_paragraph: After a six‐year hiatus, North and South Korea have resumed their “peace” negotiations. lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 24 (Reuters)—About 3,000 prisoners were released on parole today in the largest Christmas amnesty ever proclaimed in South Korea. Not included were two Japanese—a freelance journalist, Masaki Tachikawa and a college lecturer, Yoshiharu Hayakawa—who have been sentenced to 20 years in prison on charges of participation in an anti‐Government plot. The Supreme Court is to rule on their appeals.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) —The Rev. James P. Sinnott, former vicar general of Inchon, South Korea, was arrested today for conducting a prayer vigil on the grounds of the South Korean Embassy. abstract: Korea Electric will recheck safety of its nuclear power plant at Kori; Westinghouse Electric, the builder, alerted it to possible manfunction (S)

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, May 2 (AP) —South Korea will again check its only operating nuclear power plant starting Monday. lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Apri 25—President Chung Hee Park pledged publicly today that he was seeking only one more term as President while his chief lieutenants, Rim Jong Pil, told a press conference that “knowledgeable people here an ticipate that United States troops in Korea will be with drawn by 1975 except for a token force.”

abstract: SEOUL, South Korea, July 3 - Even President Carter decides to continue the freeze on American troop withdrawals from Korea, Defense Secretary Harold Brown has told South Korean leaders that the United States remains committed to their eventual withdrawal, according to senior Administration official.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, July 3 - Even President Carter decides to continue the freeze on American troop withdrawals from Korea, Defense Secretary Harold Brown has told South Korean leaders that the United States remains committed to their eventual withdrawal, according to senior Administration official.
headline.main: U.S. Said to Tell Seoul Troops Will Eventually Leave

abstract: official sources rept that S Korean Govt has imposed publicly unannounced 17% cut in oil to almost all industries, transportation and state elec power co; severe action, coupled with earlier curbs, is designed to avoid what many Koreans fear may be major crisis created by serious cutbacks in oil from Middle East; S Korea imports 85% of its oil from Arab nations; officials estimate that country is receiving about 25% less than it had contracted for; shortage comes as severe blow because country is in midst of spectacular econ expansion; Govt earlier this wk sent high-level mission headed by Choi Kyu Ha to Middle East to try to buy more oil directly from Arabs; announced on Dec 15 new Middle Eastern policy, calling for Israeli withdrawal from all occupied territories; country has also been indirectly affected by sharp cutback in imports of petroleum-based intermediate raw materials from Japan, which will have serious impact on S Korea's textile business; Koreans feel that Arab action in reducing oil supplies is highly unfair, since S Korea has no connection with Middle East crisis; Seoul described under austerity conditions
snippet: official sources rept that S Korean Govt has imposed publicly unannounced 17% cut in oil to almost all industries, transportation and state elec power co; severe action, coupled with earlier curbs, is designed to avoid what many Koreans fear may b...
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 15 — The South Korean Government has imposed a publicly unannounced 17 per cent cut on oil to almost all industries, transportation and the state electric power company, wellinformed official sources said today.

abstract: Carter Adm officials say that Pres Park's death might have been result of assassination plan carried out by Korean CIA Dir Kim Jae Kyu but there is no evidence of any wider plot involving South Korean military; officials express satisfaction that situation seems quiet and that there are no signs of North Korean troop activity; Pres Carter sends message to Prime Min Choi Kyu Hah expressing ‘deep sense of shock and sorrow’; South Korea's Defense Min Ro Jae Hyun announces that nation's military leaders will support Choi, who has been named acting Pres; illus of Ro (M)

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 — American officials said today that the death of President Park Chung Hee of South Korea might have been the result of an assassination plan carried out by the chief of Seoul's Central Intelligence Agency but that there was no evidence of any wider plot involving the South Korean military.
headline.main: ‘U.S. Aides See No Wide Plot in Seoul

abstract: Japanese leftist Opposition parties in Parliament on Sept 7 demand that Govt break diplomatic relations with S Korea and cut off econ aid to retaliate for abduction to Kim Dae Jung, S Korean Opposition party leader, from Tokyo hotel in Aug; during televised debate, Premier K Tanaka, Min M Ohira, and other mins argue that it is premature to conclude that nation's sovereignty had been violated by kidnapping but they were non-committal about future action; spokesman for Foreign Ministry tells foreign newsmen that Govt holds S Korean Govt responsible for Kim affair insofar as Korean Govt official, Kim Dong Woon, first sec in Korean Embassy in Tokyo, had been directly involved in kidnapping; police have identified Kim as Korean CIA agent; other Japanese officials indicate privately that Govt will soon declare Kim 'an unwelcome person,' as expression of protest, forcing Kim to leave country; S Korean Govt has insisted that no Govt officials, including those of CIA were involved in affair
snippet: Japanese leftist Opposition parties in Parliament on Sept 7 demand that Govt break diplomatic relations with S Korea and cut off econ aid to retaliate for abduction to Kim Dae Jung, S Korean Opposition party leader, from Tokyo hotel in Aug; during...
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Sept. 7—Japanese leftist Opposition parties demanded in Parliament today that the Government break diplomatic relations with South Korea and cut off economic aid to that, country to retaliate for the abduction of a South Korean Opposition leader here last month.
headline.main: Tokyo Leftist Parties Demand Break With Seoul
headline.print_headline: Tokyo Leftist Parties Demand Break With Seoul

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 20—President Park Chung Hee says that in five years his nation will no longer need American ground, air or naval forces or even logistic support to help defend itself if North Korea attacks without Chinese or Soviet aid.

abstract: 10,000 demonstrators converge on Japanese embassy in Seoul for 2d day in succession, but are repelled by tear gas; are protesting Japanese lack of action in arresting persons in Japan who allegedly aided in attempted assassination of Pres Park on Aug 15; demonstrators are also incensed by Japanese Foreign Min Toshio Kimura's recent statements that he thought there was no N Korean mil threat to S Korea and that he did not consider Seoul Govt as sole legitimate govt on entire Korean peninsula; Japanese Premier Tanaka reptdly is sending special envoy to Seoul in attempt to clarify Japan's position on issues disturbing relations; meanwhile, Natl Cong for Unification and Democracy coordinator Bae Dong Ho, anti-Communist foe of Park, accuses Park Govt of staging demonstrations against Japanese (M)

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 10 (AP)—Ten thousand demonstrators converged on the Japanese Embassy today for the second day in succession, but the police again fired tear gas to drive them back. The crowds made several futile attempts to break through the lines guarding the embassy, but the cordons held.
headline.main: Thousands in Seoul Again Try to Attack Japanese Embassy
headline.print_headline: Thousands in Seoul Again Try to Attack Japanese Embassy

abstract: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 3—The South Korean Government has agreed to let American officials question Tongsun Park in the United States Embassy here, according to sources close to negotiations between the two Governments over the Park case.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 3—The South Korean Government has agreed to let American officials question Tongsun Park in the United States Embassy here, according to sources close to negotiations between the two Governments over the Park case.
